title: How to Find Comfort in Drawing

steps.headline: Decide what you're going to draw.
steps.description: Usually, drawing will be most comforting when drawing something you're thinking about at that moment. Or the exact opposite. If you want to stop thinking about something, make something completely different up and try to concentrate on that.

steps.headline: Sometimes you won't have any ideas, then it's best to just start scribbling.
steps.description: Even drawing one line could give you a wonderful idea.

steps.headline: Concentrate on your drawing, and your drawing only.
steps.description: Block out everything else and try to think, feel, see, smell, hear what you are drawing.

steps.headline: Make up a story around your drawing.
steps.description: If it is something that actually happened/is happening, there is already a story of course. But you can still change that story, or add elements if you want to.

steps.headline: Fantasizing is what makes drawing so much fun.
steps.description: Whatever you draw, is entirely your own creation, even if it's based off something else. That drawing is all yours!

steps.headline: Make different versions of your drawing.
steps.description: You could make one black/white and the other in color. Or use different materials. You can change small things to give it a different effect and see which one you like best.

steps.headline: Ask others what they think when they see your drawing.
steps.description: If you want to create a certain feeling with that drawing, you must see if you've accomplished that mission.

steps.headline: Have fun while drawing!
steps.description: If you're just not feeling it, try a little longer, but it might not be the day for drawing. Everybody has those days, just try again next day or even a few hours later.

You can change small things to give it a different effect and see which one you like best. Ask others what they think when they see your drawing.
